transcripts.text: So I mean, I think you'd agree that most physicists would agree with Vigna's famous article about the unreasonable effectiveness of mathematics.  But maybe you do not agree that the effectiveness of mathematics is all that unreasonable.

No, I do not think that it is all that unreasonable that mathematics is effective in the natural sciences, because what is mathematics about?  It is a way to describe patterns, to describe regularities, and that's exactly what we do in the natural sciences.  So there is, of course, an underlying question here, which is, why is the universe such that there are patterns for us to discover to begin with?  And I think that that's a question which just falls outside of science.  So that in and by itself is not a question that belongs into my discipline.  Personally, I think that the more interesting question is, why is mathematics so inefficient in the other sciences?  Like if you look at social sciences, for example, or maybe also at neurobiology and related disciplines, there's very little mathematics that is actually being used.  I mean, I say that as a theoretical physicist.  So in physics, all our theories are mathematical.  But that's not the case in other disciplines, which brings up the question whether that is a property of nature.  Is there just a limit to what we can do with mathematics?  Or is it just a case of we have not yet found the right mathematics?
